confusion_pairs.title: Evil twin vs Rogue AP

a.definition: A malicious access point that imitates a trusted SSID to lure victims and intercept/modify traffic.

b.definition: An unauthorized access point present in the environment or connected to the network (may be accidental or malicious).

bullets: Evil twin = impersonation attack; rogue AP = unauthorized device (not always impersonating).
Evil twin targets clients; rogue AP is often an internal policy/asset control problem.
Defense: detect SSID spoofing and validate AP identity; also control the wired edge to prevent unauthorized uplinks.

confusion_pairs.title: Deauthentication vs RF jamming

a.definition: Spoofed management frames force clients off Wi‑Fi, creating a reconnection window.

b.definition: RF interference that blocks communication by drowning the signal in noise.

bullets: Deauth uses Wi‑Fi protocol frames; jamming uses radio interference.
Protected management frames (PMF) helps against deauth, not against RF jamming.
Jamming may be accidental (microwave/other RF) or malicious; deauth is almost always intentional.

confusion_pairs.title: Bluejacking vs Bluesnarfing

a.definition: Unsolicited Bluetooth messages sent to nearby devices (typically nuisance).

b.definition: Unauthorized Bluetooth access to extract data (contacts/files) from a device.

bullets: Bluejacking = spam; bluesnarfing = data theft.
Bluejacking impact is usually social/annoyance; bluesnarfing is a confidentiality incident.
Defense: disable Bluetooth when unused, enforce secure pairing modes, and block legacy insecure profiles.

confusion_pairs.title: WPA2-Personal vs WPA2-Enterprise

a.definition: Wi‑Fi security using a single shared passphrase for the whole network.

b.definition: Wi‑Fi security using per-user/device authentication via 802.1X, RADIUS, and EAP.

bullets: PSK has weak accountability; Enterprise supports unique identity and policy decisions.
If a PSK leaks, you rotate it for everyone; Enterprise can disable one user/device.
Enterprise is more complex (RADIUS/certs) but scales better for organizations.

confusion_pairs.title: WPA2 vs WPA3

a.definition: Older Wi‑Fi security generation; common, but password-based modes are more guessable and management frames may be less protected.

b.definition: Newer Wi‑Fi security generation; improves password-based authentication (SAE) and strengthens protections like PMF and forward secrecy options.

bullets: WPA3-Personal uses SAE (better than PSK).
WPA3 commonly enforces protected management frames to reduce deauth-style abuse.
Migration must consider legacy client support; design ‘best possible’ without breaking operations.

confusion_pairs.title: OWE Enhanced Open vs Captive portal

a.definition: Provides encryption on an 'open' Wi‑Fi network without requiring a shared password.

b.definition: A web-based gate for access/terms; does not inherently encrypt the Wi‑Fi link.

bullets: OWE is about link-layer encryption; captive portals are about access workflow and policy.
A captive portal can exist on an unencrypted network; OWE can encrypt without a portal.
For guests, prefer real encryption (WPA2/3 or OWE) plus portal if you need registration.

confusion_pairs.title: EAP-TLS vs PEAP

a.definition: Mutual certificate authentication (client + server certs) inside 802.1X.

b.definition: Server certificate creates a TLS tunnel; then inner authentication (often username/password).

bullets: EAP‑TLS is strongest but requires certificate lifecycle management on clients.
PEAP is easier to deploy but depends on securely validating the server certificate.
Pick based on device management maturity: unmanaged BYOD often pushes you away from client certs.

confusion_pairs.title: Geolocation vs Geofencing

a.definition: Determining where a device is (GPS/Wi‑Fi/cellular signals).

b.definition: Applying policy based on entering/leaving a defined location boundary.

bullets: Geolocation = measurement; geofencing = enforcement.
Use geolocation to find lost devices; use geofencing to block access outside allowed areas.
Location is a context signal—pair it with strong authentication, not as a standalone lock.

confusion_pairs.title: Remote wipe vs Full-device encryption

a.definition: Erase device data via management command (requires the device to receive it).

b.definition: Encrypt all device storage so offline theft doesn’t reveal data without unlock.

bullets: Remote wipe is great but not guaranteed—offline devices can ignore it.
FDE protects immediately against offline theft; pair with a strong unlock policy.
Best practice: use both—wipe for containment, FDE for theft resilience.

confusion_pairs.title: Sideloading vs Jailbreaking

a.definition: Installing apps from outside official stores, bypassing normal vetting.

b.definition: Gaining elevated OS privileges to bypass platform restrictions and controls.

bullets: Sideloading changes the app supply chain; jailbreaking changes the device trust model.
Sideloading can happen without root on some platforms; jailbreaking usually enables deeper bypass.
Defense: MDM policies to block unknown sources, plus compliance checks for rooted devices.

bluetooth.attacks.bluejacking.rule: Unsolicited Bluetooth messages—annoying, usually not data theft.

bluetooth.attacks.impersonation_bia.micro_example: Attacker mimics a headset identity to intercept pairing.

bluetooth.security_modes.rule: Bluetooth security depends on pairing mode and auth—disable/limit when not needed.
bluetooth.security_modes.micro_example: Set devices to non-discoverable and require secure pairing.

mobile.deployment.cobo.micro_example: Kiosk/warehouse scanner runs only approved apps.

mobile.deployment.cope.micro_example: Company phone allows personal apps but enforces work container rules.

mobile.deployment.cyod.rule: CYOD: org-owned, user chooses from approved devices.
mobile.deployment.cyod.micro_example: IT supports a short list of phone models to simplify security.

mobile.hardening.basic_controls.rule: Baseline mobile hardening: strong unlock + updates + least apps.

mobile.mdm.app_management.rule: MDM/UEM control: app management — enforce policy at scale.
mobile.mdm.app_management.micro_example: Policy sets app management to meet compliance.

mobile.mdm.containerization.rule: MDM/UEM control: containerization — enforce policy at scale.
mobile.mdm.containerization.micro_example: Policy sets containerization to meet compliance.

mobile.mdm.content_management.rule: MDM/UEM control: content management — enforce policy at scale.
mobile.mdm.content_management.micro_example: Policy sets content management to meet compliance.

mobile.mdm.full_device_encryption.rule: Encrypt all data at rest so theft without unlock doesn’t expose content.
mobile.mdm.full_device_encryption.micro_example: Stolen phone stays safe because storage is encrypted and locked.

mobile.mdm.geofencing.rule: Apply policy when a device crosses a boundary (inside/outside allowed zone).
mobile.mdm.geofencing.micro_example: Outside HQ geofence → block corporate apps or force VPN.

mobile.mdm.geolocation.rule: Figure out where a device is (context signal, not a lock by itself).
mobile.mdm.geolocation.micro_example: Lost phone is located via GPS/Wi‑Fi/cellular signals.

mobile.mdm.mdm_uem.rule: MDM/UEM control: mdm uem — enforce policy at scale.
mobile.mdm.mdm_uem.micro_example: Policy sets mdm uem to meet compliance.

mobile.mdm.remote_wipe.rule: Erase device data remotely—works only if the device receives the command.
mobile.mdm.remote_wipe.micro_example: Phone goes offline → wipe may not trigger; rely on encryption too.

mobile.mdm.selective_wipe.rule: MDM/UEM control: selective wipe — enforce policy at scale.
mobile.mdm.selective_wipe.micro_example: Policy sets selective wipe to meet compliance.

mobile.privacy.geotagging.rule: Location metadata in photos/docs can leak sensitive places and habits.
mobile.privacy.geotagging.micro_example: A photo shared publicly reveals the facility’s coordinates.

mobile.vuln.jailbreaking.rule: Privilege escalation/rooting to bypass OS restrictions and controls.
mobile.vuln.jailbreaking.micro_example: Rooted phone disables MDM restrictions and installs risky tools.

mobile.vuln.sideloading.rule: Installing apps from outside official stores—bypasses vetting and policy.
mobile.vuln.sideloading.micro_example: User installs an APK from a forum; malware slips in.

wifi.ap_security.rule: Harden APs: change defaults, limit admin access, patch firmware.
wifi.ap_security.micro_example: Disable unused services and restrict AP management to IT subnets.

wifi.bands.2_4ghz.rule: Band choice matters for range vs congestion (band: 2_4ghz).
wifi.bands.2_4ghz.micro_example: High-density office prefers less congested bands when clients support it.

wifi.channel_planning.rule: Plan channels/power to reduce overlap and interference.

wifi.controller_security.rule: Treat WLAN controllers like critical infrastructure: isolate, patch, log.
wifi.controller_security.micro_example: Controller admin UI on a management VLAN with MFA.

wifi.controls.protected_mgmt_frames.rule: Protect management frames so spoofed deauth/disassoc frames don’t work.
wifi.controls.protected_mgmt_frames.micro_example: Enable PMF to stop ‘kick‑off’ attacks on WPA3 WLANs.

wifi.heatmap.rule: Visual map of signal strength/coverage to guide placement and tuning.
wifi.heatmap.micro_example: Heatmap shows dead zones; add/relocate an AP.

wifi.identifiers.ssid.rule: SSID is a name, not a security control—attackers can copy it.
wifi.identifiers.ssid.micro_example: Evil twin uses your SSID to lure clients.

wifi.security.ccmp_aes.rule: AES/CCMP is the modern baseline for Wi‑Fi confidentiality/integrity.
wifi.security.ccmp_aes.micro_example: Choose CCMP over legacy WEP/TKIP for encryption.

wifi.security.owe_enhanced_open.rule: OWE encrypts traffic on ‘open’ Wi‑Fi without a shared password.
wifi.security.owe_enhanced_open.micro_example: Cafe Wi‑Fi shows as ‘open’ but your link is still encrypted (no PSK).

wifi.security.wpa2_enterprise.rule: 802.1X + RADIUS + EAP gives per-user/device auth and policy.
wifi.security.wpa2_enterprise.micro_example: Employees log in with unique creds; guests go to a separate SSID.

wifi.security.wpa2_personal.rule: Shared passphrase (PSK) Wi‑Fi—easy but weak for accountability.
wifi.security.wpa2_personal.micro_example: One PSK leaks; you must rotate it for everyone.

wifi.security.wpa3_enterprise_192bit.rule: WPA3-Enterprise can run in a stronger 192-bit security mode.
wifi.security.wpa3_enterprise_192bit.micro_example: High‑security WLAN uses WPA3‑Enterprise 192‑bit mode for sensitive users.

wifi.security.wpa3_personal_pfs.rule: WPA3 can provide forward secrecy: past traffic stays safe if a key leaks.
wifi.security.wpa3_personal_pfs.micro_example: Password leaks later; yesterday’s captures still can’t be decrypted.

wifi.security.wpa3_personal_sae.rule: WPA3-Personal uses SAE instead of PSK to resist offline guessing.
wifi.security.wpa3_personal_sae.micro_example: Weak password hurts less because attackers can’t grab a hash and crack offline.

wifi.site_survey.rule: Survey the RF environment before deployment to avoid coverage and security surprises.
wifi.site_survey.micro_example: Walk the floor and record interference/coverage before installing APs.

wifi.threats.deauth_disassoc.rule: Protocol-frame attack that kicks clients off so they reconnect (often to a trap).
wifi.threats.deauth_disassoc.micro_example: Attacker spams deauth frames, forcing a laptop to reconnect.

wifi.threats.evil_twin.rule: Fake AP that clones a trusted SSID to trick clients.
wifi.threats.evil_twin.micro_example: You see 'CorpWiFi' twice; the stronger one is attacker-controlled.

wifi.threats.jamming.rule: RF interference that blocks communication by drowning the signal.
wifi.threats.jamming.micro_example: A jammer or noisy device wipes out Wi‑Fi on a channel.

wifi.threats.rogue_ap.rule: Unauthorized AP in/near your environment (may be accidental or malicious).
wifi.threats.rogue_ap.micro_example: Employee plugs in a cheap router; it bridges into the LAN.

wireless.auth.8021x.rule: Port/AP-based access control that requires authentication before joining.
wireless.auth.8021x.micro_example: Wi‑Fi denies association until 802.1X auth succeeds.

wireless.auth.eap.rule: Authentication framework used inside 802.1X (many EAP methods).
wireless.auth.eap.micro_example: Choose PEAP or EAP‑TLS based on certificate readiness.

wireless.auth.eap_fast.rule: EAP method designed for faster (re)authentication, useful for roaming.
wireless.auth.eap_fast.micro_example: Warehouse scanners roam APs without slow reauth delays.

wireless.auth.eap_peap.rule: Server cert + TLS tunnel, then inner auth (often username/password).
wireless.auth.eap_peap.micro_example: PEAP protects credentials inside TLS even on untrusted airwaves.

wireless.auth.eap_tls.rule: Strong mutual certificate auth (client + server certs).
wireless.auth.eap_tls.micro_example: Corp laptops use EAP‑TLS with device certificates.

wireless.auth.eap_ttls.rule: TLS tunnel method that can avoid client certs while still protecting auth.
wireless.auth.eap_ttls.micro_example: TTLS lets users authenticate with passwords inside a TLS tunnel.

wireless.auth.open_captive_portal.rule: Web page gate for access; doesn’t automatically encrypt the Wi‑Fi link.
wireless.auth.open_captive_portal.micro_example: Hotel portal accepts terms, but you still need HTTPS/VPN on the session.

wireless.auth.psk.rule: Single shared Wi‑Fi secret—no per-user identity.
wireless.auth.psk.micro_example: Contractor learns the PSK; you can’t tell who used it.

wireless.auth.radius.rule: Central auth server used by 802.1X to validate users/devices.
wireless.auth.radius.micro_example: AP forwards login to RADIUS; RADIUS returns accept/deny.

wireless.auth.radius_federation.rule: Federated RADIUS lets users authenticate via home org credentials across domains.
wireless.auth.radius_federation.micro_example: Visitors use their university login on your guest enterprise WLAN.
